user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_time_t *abs_wakeup_time)
{
    struct timespec                    limit;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    limit.tv_sec  = OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(*abs_wakeup_time);
    limit.tv_nsec = OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(*abs_wakeup_time);

    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_timedwait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut, &limit);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
    }
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    int64 ticks; /**< Ticks elapsed since reference point */
} OS_time_t
...
static inline int64 OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (tm.ticks / OS_TIME_TICKS_PER_SECOND);
}
...
static inline uint32 OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (uint32)OS_TimeGetFractionalPart(tm) * OS_TIME_TICK_RESOLUTION_NS;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
static void OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex(void *mut)
{
    pthread_mutex_unlock(mut);
}
...
#define OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT (-4)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code fragments. Specific notes:

- pthread_cleanup_push / pthread_cleanup_pop: These are POSIX thread library macros (part of pthreads), not compiler-specific language extensions. They are library macros that must be used as a matching pair and do not require compiler-specific extensions such as GCC nested functions or statement-expressions.

- pthread_cond_timedwait, pthread_mutex_unlock, pthread_cond_t, pthread_mutex_t, and struct timespec: These are POSIX types and functions from the standard C/POSIX libraries, not compiler language extensions.

- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET is a plain C macro that expands to an address-of indexing expression; using macros is standard C and not a compiler extension.

- static inline, typedefs (int64, uint32), boolean literal false, and the other helper inline functions are standard C (C99 or later) constructs, not compiler-specific extensions.

- No use of known compiler-specific extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values, or other vendor-specific keywords/macros is present in the shown code.

Therefore there are no fragments requiring investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions).
